facts.text: Petitions Nos. 67, 87 and 130 of 1959 filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging constitutionality of s. 19(3) of Slum Areas Improvement and Clearance Act 1956

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petitions Nos. 67, 87 and 130 of 1959. Petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights. S. Narula and S. S. Chadha, for the petitioners. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General of India, B. Sen and T. Sen, for Respondents Nos. 1, 2 and 5  In petition No. 83 of 1959  1, 2 and 12  In Petition No. 67 of 1959  and 1, 2 and 4  In Petition No. 130 of 1959 .

facts.text: Petitioner Jyoti Pershad is owner of a house in Delhi with respondents 3 to 11 as tenants each occupying a single room

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner-Jyoti Pershad-is the owner of a house in Delhi in which respondents 3 to 11 were tenants. Each of these nine individuals occupied a single room in this house.

facts.text: Petitioner submitted plan to Delhi Municipal Committee for reconstruction of house and obtained sanction

anchor.surface_text: As the petitioner considered the house to be old and required to be demolished and reconstructed, he submitted a plan to the Council of the Delhi Municipal Committee and applied for sanction for the reconstruction of the house. The plan was sanctioned

facts.text: Petitioner filed suits against nine tenants under s.13(1)(g) of Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act 1952

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter the petitioner filed suits against these nine tenants under s. 13(1)(g) of the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act 38 of 1952, which will hereafter be referred to as the Rent Control Act.

facts.text: Civil Court in Delhi passed decrees for eviction of respondents 3 to 11 on December 8, 1956

anchor.surface_text: On December 8, 1956 the Civil Court in Delhi passed decrees in favour of the petitioner for the eviction of respondents 3 to 11.

facts.text: Decrees granted three months time for tenants to vacate premises

anchor.surface_text: The tenants, however, refused to give up possession within the three months time granted to them by the decrees to vacate the premises

facts.text: Tenants appealed eviction orders to Senior Sub-Judge Delhi under s.34 Rent Control Act, appeals disposed against tenants by end of October 1957

anchor.surface_text: but went up in appeal against the orders of eviction under s. 34 of the Rent Control Act to the Senior Sub-Judge, Delhi. These appeals were finally disposed of against the tenant-appellants, some on the merits and some by reason of abatement, by the end of October, 1957.

facts.text: Sanction for reconstruction lapsed due to one year rule from Delhi Municipal Committee

anchor.surface_text: Under the rules governing the construction of houses on plans sanctioned by the Delhi Municipal Committee, the sanctioned building had to be completed within a period of one year from the date of sanction. As a result of this rule the sanction obtained by the petitioner lapsed

facts.text: Slum Areas Improvement and Clearance Act 1956 (Central Act 96 of 1956) enacted and came into force in Delhi area

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, two changes came about in the law governing matters relevant to the present case The first was that the Slum Areas Improvement and Clearance Act 96 of 1956, which will be hereafter referred to as the Act, was enacted by Parliament and came into force in the Delhi area.

facts.text: Petitioner filed nine applications under s.19 of Slum Act before competent authority for eviction based on decrees

anchor.surface_text: Thus freed from obligation to the tenants the petitioner filed on the strength of these decrees for eviction nine applications under s. 19 of the Act before the competent authority for the eviction of the tenants from the nine rooms in the building

facts.text: Competent authority dismissed applications on January 13, 1958 as sanction had expired

anchor.surface_text: These petitions were dismissed by the competent authority by his order dated January 13, 1958 on the ground that the sanction to reconstruct the building which the petitioner had obtained from the municipality in 1956 had expired.

facts.text: Petitioner obtained fresh sanction for building with three living rooms

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the petitioner applied to the municipal authorities for sanctioning a building plan. As stated earlier, the building plan approved by the municipality could permit only a building consisting of one floor in which there were three living rooms and sanction for the construction

facts.text: Renewed applications under s.19 dismissed by competent authority on July 30, 1958 on grounds of hardship to poor tenants

anchor.surface_text: With this sanctioned plan, the petitioner renewed his application under s. 19 for permission to execute the decree of the Civil Court and evict the tenants. By order dated July 30, 1958 all these applications were dismissed.

facts.text: Petitioner appealed to Administrator of Union Territory Delhi under s.20 Slum Act, appeals dismissed

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner preferred appeals against this order to the Administrator of the Union Territory, Delhi to whom appeals lay under s. 20 of the Act. The appeals were dismissed,

facts.text: Petitioner moved Supreme Court for writ of certiorari to quash orders challenging s.19 as violative of Arts.14 and 19(1)(f)

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances the petitioner has moved this Court for the issue of a writ of certiorari to quash these orders on the ground already adverted to, viz., that s. 19 of the Act is invalid and unconstitutional as violative of the petitioners rights guaranteed by Arts. 14 and 19(1)(f) of the Constitution.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by AYYANGAR J. on April 21, 1961

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-These three petitions have been filed invoking the jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging the constitutionality

facts.text: Petitioner proved sanctioned plan providing accommodation for tenants and funds deposited in State Bank of India

anchor.surface_text: Two matters had to be proved under s. 13(1)(g) of the Rent Control Act by a plaintiff before he could obtain an order of eviction (i) that there was a plan which had been sanctioned by the municipal authorities which made, provision for the tenants then in occupation of the house being accommodated in the house as reconstructed, and (ii) that the plaintiff had the necessary funds to carry out the reconstruction.

facts.text: Tenants refused to deliver possession within specified date under s.15 Rent Control Act, losing right to reinstatement

anchor.surface_text: It would have been noticed that the right of the tenants to insist on the landlord providing accommodation for them in the reconstructed building guaranteed to them by s. 15 of the Rent Control Act, had ceased by reason of their failure to quit and deliver vacant possession of the tenements occupied by them within 3 months fixed by the order of the Civil Court vide s. 15

facts.text: Revised municipal regulations prohibit double-storeyed buildings in the area, allowing only three living rooms

anchor.surface_text: the type of constructions that could be sanctioned by the Delhi Municipal Committee underwent a radical alteration as a result of which in the area in question double-storeyed buildings were not permitted to be constructed and that if the petitioners house had to be reconstructed it could only have three living rooms

facts.text: House described as in dilapidated condition by petitioner in s.19 applications

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that the building had to be reconstructed as it was in a dilapidated condition. These petitions were dismissed by the competent authority

facts.text: Administrator dismissed appeals stating property not declared unfit, to prevent eviction of poor from slums

anchor.surface_text: the appellate authority saying I would have allowed the appellant permission to evict the tenants, if the property itself was dilapidated and declared unfit for human habitation by a competent authority. This is not so.

facts.text: Tenants are old, poor, paying Rs.3 per month rent, no complaint about condition

anchor.surface_text: They are old tenants and as stated above also very poor. The execution of the decree will involve very real hardship to them. They are all occupying only one Kothri each and paying rent at Rs. 3 per mensem, and they have no complaint to make about the condition of their Kothries.

facts.text: Petitions dismissed by Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: We therefore consider that none of the points urged in support of the petition has any substance. The petitions fail and are dismissed.

issues.text: Whether Section 19 of the Slum Areas (Improvement and Clearance) Act, 1956, particularly sub-section 3, is unconstitutional as violative of Articles 14 and 19(1)(f) of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging the companystitutionality of s. 19 and particularly sub-s. 3, of the Slum Areas Improvement and Clearance Act 1956 (Central Act 96 of 1956), on the ground that it offends the fundamental right of the petitioners guaranteed to them by Arts. 14 and 19(1)(f). To appreciate the grounds on which this companytention is sought to be sustained it is necessary to set

issues.text: Whether Section 19(3) of the Act vests an unguided, unfettered and uncontrolled power in an executive officer to withhold permission to execute a decree, thereby offending Article 14 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: They were mainly three  1  Section 19 3  of the Act vests an unguided, unfettered and uncontrolled power in an executive officer to withhold permission to execute a decree which a landlord has obtained after satisfying the reasonable requirements of the law as enacted in the Rent Control Act. Neither s. 19 of the Act number any other provision of the Act indicates the grounds on which the companypetent authority might grant or withhold permission to execute decrees and the power companyferred is, therefore, arbitrary and offends Art. 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the power conferred on the competent authority by Section 19(3) of the Act constitutes excessive delegation of legislative power and is therefore unconstitutional?

anchor.surface_text: 2  The same point was urged in a slightly different form by saying that the Power companyferred on the companypetent authority by s. 19 3  of the Act was an excessive delegation of legislative power and was, therefore, unconstitutional.

issues.text: Whether Section 19 of the Act imposes an unreasonable restriction on the right to hold property under Article 19(1)(f), not saved by Article 19(5)?

anchor.surface_text: 3  The vesting of a power in an executive authority to override-at his sweet will and pleasure-rights to property without any guidance from the Legislature company stituted an unreasonable restraint on the petitioners right to hold property, a right which in the case of the property of the type number in question would include a right to obtain possession from the tenant in order either to improve it by reconstruction or for the purpose of his own use.

issues.text: Whether the general question of the constitutionality of Section 19 of the Act is the only issue before the Court, not the validity of particular orders?

anchor.surface_text: In passing we may observe that we are number companycerned with the validity of the particular orders passed in the case but only with the general question as to the companystitutionality of the impugned s. 19 of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Validity not dependent on being in same Act; necessary in context

holdings.text: Section 19 of the Slum Areas (Improvement and Clearance) Act, 1956 is not violative of Article 14 as there is sufficient guidance for the competent authority's discretion from the policy and purpose of the Act evident in the preamble and operative provisions.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the foregoing we consider that there is enough guidance to the competent authority in the use of his discretion under s. 19 1  of the Act and we, therefore, reject the contention that s. 19 is obnoxious to the equal protection of laws guaranteed by Art. 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy gathered from preamble (slum improvement/clearance and tenant protection), chapters II-VI detailing processes, rational relation to object; precedents like Dalmia, Bagla, Anwar Ali Sarkar confirm policy suffices as guidance.

holdings.text: The guidance provided bears a reasonable and rational relationship to the object of the Act, namely orderly elimination of slums with interim protection for tenants.

anchor.surface_text: We need only add that it was not, and could not be, disputed that the guidance which we have held could be derived from the enactment, and that it bears a reasonable and rational relationship to the object to be attained by the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly links extracted policy to Act's goals of slum eradication and tenant safeguard during transition.

holdings.text: Section 19(3) does not constitute excessive delegation of legislative power.

anchor.surface_text: The next point argued by learned Counsel for the petitioner was that the power conferred on the competent authority by s. 19 3  of the Act was an excessive delegation of legislative power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same policy guidance as for Art.14 objection suffices; legislature need not detail every application if purpose laid down.

holdings.text: The restriction imposed by Section 19 on the right to hold property under Article 19(1)(f) is reasonable and saved by Article 19(5).

anchor.surface_text: Judged in the light of the above, we consider that the restrictions imposed cannot be said to be unreasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Temporary ban, public interest in slum dwellers' health/safety, safeguards (hearing, inquiry, appeal, quasi-judicial), rational connection to object; contextual to post-partition housing crisis.

holdings.text: The Court is concerned only with the constitutionality of Section 19, not the validity of particular orders passed thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: In passing we may observe that we are not concerned with the validity of the particular orders passed in the case but only with the general question as to the constitutionality of the impugned s. 19 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition under Art.32 challenges provision's validity, not administrative application.

holdings.text: Section 39 of the Slum Act contains a non-obstante clause prevailing over Section 38 of the Rent Control Act; Slum Act provisions operate in addition to Rent Control Act for slum areas post-decree.

anchor.surface_text: s. 39 of the Act also contains a non obstante clause on the same lines as s. 38 of the Rent Control Act. The result therefore would be that the provisions of the special enactment, as the Act is, will in respect of the buildings in areas declared slum areas operate in addition to the Rent Control Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of non-obstante clauses; special law adds to general post-decree stage.

holdings.text: The petitions fail and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore consider that none of the points urged in support of the petition has any substance. The petitions fail and are dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All constitutional challenges rejected on merits.

holdings.text: Competent authority under s.19 acts quasi-judicially, bound by natural justice (hearing, inquiry), with appeal safeguard.

anchor.surface_text: The procedure laid down by the Act for the hearing by the competent authority and the provisions for enquiry, renders the competent authority a quasi-judicial functionary bound to follow fixed rules of procedure and its orders passed after such an enquiry are to be subject to appeals to the Administrator.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit in s.19(2); enhances reasonableness under Art.19(5).

holdings.text: The grounds for refusal by competent authority in this case align with the Act's policy.

anchor.surface_text: We are further of the opinion that the order of the competent authority in the present case is not open to challenge either, because it would be seen that the grounds upon which he has rejected the petitioners application for execution is in line with what we have stated to be the policy and purpose of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hardship to tenants, non-dilapidation consistent with interim protection till clearance.

Messrs. Dwarka Prasad Laxmi Narain v. The State of Uttar Pradesh  2 .  2  1954 C.R. 803. 813.

precedents.cited_proposition: commits to the unrestrained will of a single individual the power to grant, withhold or cancel licences... no check upon injustice

precedents.citation: The State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar 1 1952 S.C.R. 284

anchor.surface_text: possibly the best instance of this type of case is afforded by the legislation under consideration in The State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar  1 , the ratio underlying which was thus explained in Kathi Raning Rawat v. The State of Saurashtra  2  If it depends entirely upon the pleasure of the State Government to make any classification it likes, without any guiding principle at all, it cannot certainly be a proper classification, which requires that a reasonable relation must exist between the classification and the objective that the legislation has in view.  1  1952 S.C.R. 284.

precedents.case_name: The State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar
precedents.cited_proposition: instance of legislation enabling discriminatory treatment without policy or purpose

precedents.citation: Kathi Raning Rawat v. The State of Saurashtra 2 1952 S.C.R. 435, 461, 462

anchor.surface_text: the ratio underlying which was thus explained in Kathi Raning Rawat v. The State of Saurashtra  2  If it depends entirely upon the pleasure of the State Government to make any classification it likes, without any guiding principle at all, it cannot certainly be a proper classification, which requires that a reasonable relation must exist between the classification and the objective that the legislation has in view. On the other hand, if the legislature indicates a definite objective and the discretion has been vested in the State Government as a means of achieving that object, the law itself cannot be held to be discriminatory, though the action of the State Government may be condemned if it offends against the equal protection clause, by making an arbitrary selection.  2  1952 S.C.R. 435, 461, 462.

precedents.case_name: Kathi Raning Rawat v. The State of Saurashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: explanation of ratio in Anwar Ali Sarkar: classification must have reasonable relation to objective; discretion okay if policy indicated

precedents.citation: Kedar Nath Bajoria v. The State of West Bengal 1 1934 S. C. R. 30, 46

anchor.surface_text: The Saurashtra case would seem to lay down the principle that if the impugned legislation indicates the policy which inspired it and the object which it seeks to attain, the mere fact that the legislation does not itself make a complete and precise classification of the persons or things to which it is to be applied, but leaves the selective application of the law to be made by the standard indicated or the underlying policy and object disclosed is not a sufficient ground for condemning it as arbitrary and, therefore, obnoxious to article 14. Kedar Nath Bajoria v. The State of West Bengal  1  .  1  1934 S. C. R. 30, 46.

precedents.case_name: Kedar Nath Bajoria v. The State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: legislation not arbitrary if it indicates policy and object, even if selective application left to authority guided by that

precedents.citation: Harishankar Bagla and another v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 1 1935 1 C.R. 380, 388

anchor.surface_text: Harishankar Bagla and another v. The State of Madhya Pradesh  1  . Such guidance may thus be obtained from or afforded by  a  the preamble read in the light of the surrounding circumstances which necessitated the legislation, taken in conjunction with well-known facts of which the Court might take judicial notice or of which it is appraised by evidence before it in the form of affidavits, Kathi Raning Rawat v. The State of Saurashtra  3  being an instance where the guidance was gathered in the manner above indicated,  1  1935 1 C.R. 380, 388.

precedents.case_name: Harishankar Bagla and another v. The State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: guidance from preamble and surrounding circumstances

precedents.citation: Kathi Raning Rawat v. The State of Saurashtra 3 1052 S.C.R. 435, 461, 462

anchor.surface_text: Kathi Raning Rawat v. The State of Saurashtra  3  being an instance where the guidance was gathered in the manner above indicated,  b  or even from the policy and purpose of the enactment which may be gathered from other operative provisions applicable to analogous or comparable situations or generally from the object sought to be achieved by the enactment.  3  1052 S.C.R. 435, 461, 462.

precedents.case_name: Kathi Raning Rawat v. The State of Saurashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: instance where guidance gathered from preamble and circumstances

precedents.citation: Harishankar Bagla v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 1 1955 1 S.C.R. 380, 388

anchor.surface_text: The policy underlying the Order is to regulate the transport of cotton textile in a manner that will ensure an even distribution of the commodity in the country and make it available at a fair price to all. The grant or refusal of a permit is thus to be governed by this policy and the discretion given to the Textile Commissioner is to be exercised in such a way as to effectuate this policy. The conferment of such a discretion cannot be called invalid and if there is an abuse of the power there is ample power in the Courts to undo the mischief. Harishankar Bagla v. The State of Madhya Pradesh  1 .  1  1955 1 S.C.R. 380, 388.

precedents.case_name: Harishankar Bagla v. The State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: policy from object of enactment provides guidance; abuse correctable by courts

precedents.citation: Pannalal Binjraj v. Union of India 2 1957 S.C.R. 233

anchor.surface_text: In Pannalal Binjraj v. Union of Indias case  2  the purpose of the provision which was administrative convenience for enabling assessments to be made in the manner indicated by the Income-tax Act was held to afford a sufficient guidance so as to render the provision immune from attack on the ground of violation of Art. 14.  2  1957 S.C.R. 233.

precedents.case_name: Pannalal Binjraj v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: administrative convenience as purpose affords sufficient guidance against Art. 14 challenge
